result.execSummary:
The defendant Thomas Joseph Johnson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Operating While Intoxicated - 8th Offense, a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

charges.descr: Operate Motor Vehicle While Revoked, Repeater

supervisions.notes: Jackson County Case No. 15 CM 38 is Dismissed and Read-In.  Dodge Correctional as reception center.  Prison wages are to be used to pay restitution, fine and court costs.  Defendant is eligible for the Earned Release Program (Substance Abuse Program).

superMiscConds.notes: $600 fine and costs.  Prison wages are to be used to pay fine and costs.

Restitution Ordered:  $500.00 - T.J.; $12,052.91 - L.N.; $11,190.59 - WI Mutual; $547.07 - Kwik Trip (Jackson Co. Case No. 15 CM 38); $2,429.06 - surcharge.  Prison wages are to be used to pay restitution.
Defendant is to pay the IID and the DNA surcharges.  Defendant is to pay the blood draw fee.  Prison wages are to be used to pay costs.
Defendant is to receive an AODA evaluation and follow through with any treatment.
Defendant is to comply with any treatment/programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and agent.

supervisions.notes: Any vehicle(s) titled in the Defendant's name and/or any vehicle(s) operated by the Defendant are subject to an ignition interlock device.  The ignition interlock requirement becomes effective when the Defendant applies for a license.
Defendant is to receive an alcohol assessment and comply with any driver's safety plan.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea
